name: Stephanie Hanrahan
bio:
Wife to a sick husband
Mother to two autistic kiddos
A woman who made her private journal public
Now I speak 🎤 write 📝 host 🎙and talk on TEDx👇

social_posts.post_text:
Dear Jax,

The first time my daughter met you it was to write a song about autism. We thought we were there to collaborate. To bring awareness to neurodiversity. I assumed she’d sing and we’d never see you again.

Who knew you’d soon feel like family.

Some celebrities gain status and become unreachable. They trade in their passion for praise and fandom. They forget they were once little girls with braided hair and big dreams.

But I knew you were different right away. You got on the floor with Campbell. You validated the things she had to say. You didn’t see her autism as a missing piece; you embraced the beautifully whole human she’s always been.

We were with you the day Victoria’s Secret dropped. We talked about releasing truth and not worrying about response. That a creatives job is to tell a story and set it free. Now, six months later, here you are: your very first stadium tour. Campbell’s very first concert.

Your impact on people’s lives is wide and deep and it’s not just because you write incredible songs; it’s because your authenticity is palpable. And people want real.

Thank you for giving my daughter her first guitar and permission to use her superpower (autism).

I wish somebody would’ve told me when I was younger—people like you exist.

#autism #neurodiversity #disabilityawareness #autismacceptance

We had 24 hours to clean out a Uhaul full of boxes and best laid plans.

Just because I’m a founder of a nonprofit doesn’t mean I don’t benefit from what it offers. When our retreat was cancelled, us fearless leaders crumbled.

We crave connection as much as anyone.

So I set out to make our 24 hours together as connective as possible (and some very special people helped offset our sadness too):

@grapes_and_gouda_dallastx whose prosciutto and brie blessed our bellies and nourished our souls.
@stretchlabfrisco who lengthened and strengthened our bodies after hours of unloading boxes 
@fon.massage.wellness whose hands are from God. She came to our Airbnb while we were working and made us forget who we were for a few hours.
@breathemeditationandwellness who bathed us in sound, centered our souls, and gave me a very ironic intention (watch the video until the end).

Here’s the thing:

You can heal and hurt simultaneously. You can lead others and still need someone to encircle you. Us founders were strangers before we formed this nonprofit. Now we are family.

Tell me God’s hand isn’t in that?

Community—being with women who understand you—will save your life.

It’s the mission of Labeled and Loved—and for 24 hours, we remembered why.

#disabilityinclusion #specialneedsmom #specialneedsfamily #autismmom #disabilityawareness #caregiversupport #autismblog

I often get asked why autism is on the rise. 

Let me preface this by saying, I am not a diagnostician. I’m sure there are a lot of people with a lot of acronyms behind their name that can tell you their thoughts.

But both of my children are autistic, which means I am knee-deep in the world of neurodiversity and have some observations of my own:

Autism isn’t necessarily on the rise—we’re just finally getting better at identifying it.

A few decades ago to receive a diagnosis you had to display some pretty severe and stereotypical symptoms. Research was limited and physicians and psychologists had narrow criteria to compare against.

But what we know now about the spectrum is not what we knew then. My children wouldn’t have been diagnosed decades ago and they are very much autistic. In fact, I know several parents who have only recently received a diagnosis in their 40’s and 50’s after their own children were diagnosed.

If I’m being brutally honest, I see autism everywhere now that I know what I’m looking for.

I know it’s tempting to want to know the why behind autism; what’s causing it? But neurodiversity isn’t some scary, dangerous thing—lack of support is.

So maybe the question shouldn’t be what’s causing autism to rise, but rather how we can support a group of people who have been with us all along.

#autismawareness #autismacceptance #autismingirls #autismmom #inclusion #autismsupport #disability #neurodiversity

Campbell’s best friend left their annual sleepover in tears.

The reason? She didn’t want to go home.

She told her mom she wished Campbell was her sister; that they would always be together. She said while other kids can be nice, sometimes they’re mean too. But that’s never the case with Campbell. She’s consistently kind.

It was my turn to cry.

It’s one thing to accept my child. It’s another thing to choose her.

Bryn chooses Campbell because she sees what she offers as valuable. It doesn’t take any convincing. It’s not a relationship based on pity; it’s pure admiration (and it’s reciprocal).

I know as an adult how rare of a find that kind of friend is.

There are people out there who will not just tolerate your child, but love them fiercely. They are the few, but hey, Jesus only had twelve best friends and he was pretty perfect.

All we need is one.

Thank you @southernsleepoversdallas for creating this wonderland for two magical little girls.

And thank you, Bryn, for being our one.

#autismrocks #autisminclusion #neurodiverse #autismingirls #disabilityawareness

You’re a mean one, Mr. Hanrahan.

Our Grinch sleepover wouldn’t have been complete without a very special guest stopping by the next morning. The kids had the best reaction and our inquisitive Eli saved the day.

Thanks to my husband who is the implementer of all my crazy ideas.

You’re as cuddly as a cactus (and the talk of the neighborhood now).

#girlswithautism #autismingirls #boyswithautism #specialneedsdad #specialneedsfamily #autismmom #autismblogger

Dear Kanye,

It seems like the vast majority of the world (and social media) are against you right now.

And so, you believed this was the right time to declare yourself as autistic.

There is no doubt in my mind this may be truth.

There is also no doubt in my mind that you are undoing the work of so many autism advocates.

We already fight so hard to not have our children’s capabilities called into question. Every day I have to prove my kids worth. It’s an unfair stigma based upon a world that prioritizes convenience and productivity above all else, and at your lowest, professionally and personally, you decide to join our ranks.

When my children apply for a job, will employers only associate their brilliance with you and Rain Man?

What about all the beautiful minds in between? 

While I’m happy neurodiversity is getting the spotlight, I’m also concerned instability will be associated with the spectrum even more than it already is. And that’s so unfair.

I guess what I wish is that at people’s best they claimed their autism. That it was a badge of honor, not some invisible indiscretion.

I guess I wish there was a boy and a girl like mine that became the image the world sees when they think of neurodiversity.

Beautiful and whole. Kind and capable.

Those are the people on the spectrum that deserve front page news.

#autism #girlswithautism #boyswithautism #autismfamily #autismmom #autismblog #inclusion #disabilityawareness #specialneedsmom

When she was two, her dad almost died.

She has no recollection of that: the flatline—or the fact that we still live on borrowed time.

She doesn’t remember how many episodes of Daniel Tiger he watched with her as a preschooler, or how he hands over every paycheck to make the quality of her life as easy as possible.

Shawn has waited quietly in the wings for Campbell to come around, often with no acknowledgment. But a few weeks ago, they had their win: a high school football game.

Or as he called it, “My best experience with her.”

I hope one day she’ll understand the significance of her father’s love. That with less words, he says more. That he is a father who is steady and constant and good, and most importantly, that he has never rushed her. He’s met her exactly where she’s at.

He’s patiently waited for her to arrive.

#girlswithautism #autismdad #autismblog #specialneedsfamily #disabilityawareness #neurodivergent

I never expected she’d ask Santa for this 🥹♥️

#girlswithautism #autismrocks #specialneedsmom #autismmom

For the first four years of his life, Eli wouldn’t open a single present. Every Christmas he’d run into his bedroom and hide and my heart would break into a thousand pieces.

Now, at age six, he’s shopping for his sister.

We’ve all come so far.

Well, except the one thing you’ll see in this video we still can’t do.

May the thrill of hope carry you through the days of heartbreak.

Anything can happen. Anything can be.

#autismfamily #boyswithautism #autistickids #autismmom #sensoryoverload #autismblog #specialneedsmom

Someone feels a little betrayed this holiday season.

#dogrescue #dogadoption #animalrescue #autismblogger

I just keep thinking about Mary. About how under-qualified and unprepared she was.

And yet, she showed up when called.

Sounds like a lot of other mothers I know.

I once read God doesn’t call the equipped—he equips the called. Certainly summarizes my special needs journey. I’ve never had the right credentials to parent these kids, but somehow every step has been blessed.

Merry Christmas—especially to the mothers who carry the daily cross of parenting a child with a disability.

It’s never the shiny, perfect people God uses for his glory. World changers are the ones you never see coming.

They are the mothers. They are the baby in a manger.

#autismmom #autismblog #specialneedsfamily #disabilityawareness

Things I want to remember from our Christmas Day:

🕯️ Campbell’s first Christmas Eve service. How I never thought I’d look to my left and see my daughter in the same sanctuary as me. You want to experience God? Worship with his children.

📝 Eli’s handwritten note to Dad (more to come on this one).

🧸 Shawn running to Walgreens to get batteries and continuing to play with the kids long after I grew tired of the new toys.

👼🏼 Feeling like I don’t want to be anywhere else. Every year until now, I’ve had Christmas envy. I’ve wanted bigger or busier. I’ve wanted to outrun my reality—and now I just want to sit in it. Crossing over the contentment bridge is a big one for me.

You see, I won’t remember what we ate or opened. I could careless that the cookies were store bought or that we grilled steaks instead of baking ham. Within these four walls, with these four people, magic happened.

O Holy Night, indeed.

#autismfamily #specialneedsfamily #autismmom #autismblog

I’m binging again.

Bingeing. Restricting. Body obsessing. I’m in the process of changing medications and it’s making me unable to control my impulses. If that sounds ridiculous, then count yourself among the lucky ones who don’t have to deal with mental health issues or food addiction.

So I’ve been resetting with the health program I used a few years ago. Not necessarily to lose weight (in 2020 I lost 35 pounds in 12 weeks and have maintained since), but to gain control. I know myself. I need parameters. I need a coach for accountability. I need the ease of food delivered to my door. Foods filled with 100% of my daily vitamins, minerals, and probiotics. When things spin, I hold steady to what I can.

Food doesn’t fix my circumstances—in fact, overeating just makes me less equipped to fight my battles.

So to my current clients—or anyone new who wants to work toward their health goals with a coach who is very flawed but also very hardworking and honest—I’m here. We can do this together.

I am strong and capable.

I am healthy, in body and mind.

I am just getting started.

#mentalhealth #bodydysmorphia #momswithanxiety #autismmom #ptsdrecovery

This is the second Christmas where Campbell has asked for only one thing: Santa’s magic. She wants nothing more than to make her own miracles happen here on this earth.

Last year, I skirted by without addressing it. This year, when she asked again, I knew it was time for the truth.

Santa can’t give you his magic, my girl—because it isn’t his to give.

May every child (and adult) believe with a heart like hers.

#autism #girlswithautism #asd #autismfamily #neurodivergent #autismblogger

Cheers to the new year…and the continent? 🤔

#specialneedsfamily #autismawareness #kidswithautism #disabilityawareness #autismmom #autismblog

Well, that was on par 🫠 Happy New Year from two totally different kiddos.

Are you more like Campbell or Eli for 2023? I think I’m a mix of both.

#autismfamily #autismsiblings #boyswithautism #girlswithautism #neurodiversity #disabilityawareness

Two children. Same diagnosis. Same genetics. Same household. Totally different humans.

She’s my dreamer. He’s my doer.

She craves center stage. He’s comfortable behind the scenes.

She spoke early and often. He still has articulation and expressive speech delays.

Our family could be a case study on autism and nature vs. nurture.

My point is, autism doesn’t take away someone’s ability to be uniquely human. Every person on the spectrum is different, not just from the general population, but from each other too. So it’s time we stop lumping people with autism into one stereotype.

(I’m looking at you Hollywood with your portrayal of quirky chemists and physicians.)

People with autism have personalities and ambitions, and yes, limitations—just like everyone else.

Let’s love and learn someone beyond their label.

Let’s put a person first.

#autismfamily #girlswithautism #autismawareness #disability #neurodivergent #autismblogger

To my husband on our 10 year anniversary,

You are not my soul mate nor my best friend.

Those titles imply you are my everything, which means if you go before me, my life will end too.

And you’d never want that. In fact, you’ve spent the last ten years smoothing the road so that, with or without you, I’m capable enough to walk it.

And that’s what I credit to our survival: your unselfish love. You have given me space to be an individual inside of our union. You have given me children and a community and life full of resounding yes’. We may not stay up late swinging from the chandeliers, but with you, I am safe. And as I age, as the rug continues to get pulled out from underneath us, I find immense value in that.

I don’t know what lies ahead (I’m willing to believe the best does), but after ten years, here’s what our marriage means to me:

I can exist without you—but I really don’t want to.

And maybe that’s what love is really all about. You don’t become someone’s whole world, you show them the world—and yet they still choose to return home to you.

Do you hear him?

Do not be afraid. Do not lose hope.

Even if you’re a nonbeliever maybe you’ll believe the boy in front of you. The one who used to have no words. The one who, when the words did come, stuttered and stammered and shied away from speaking in public.

Now here he is at age six. Standing in front of a group of his peers, professing his faith.

There are so many times I had everything but hope. Fear is in my DNA. Worry runs through my veins.

But then I look at this unexpected life I’ve been given and think, “My gosh, there are miracles everywhere.” Not just big hallelujah moments, but tiny drips of heaven I otherwise would’ve overlooked if autism hadn’t broken me open.

Like a boy in a room reciting scripture.

Do not be afraid. Do not lose hope.

#autism #boyswithautism #autismmom #autismlove #disabilityadvocate #neurodiversefamily

Here’s what I love about this little girl:

She starts cheering before she even knows she made the basket.

The outcome is irrelevant; it’s the effort she’s applauding.

Imagine how rich our lives would be if we celebrated taking the shot as much as making the shot.

There are a lot of things that can be learned from autism.

One of which is how to truly win.

#autismfamily #girlsonthespectrum #asd #autismmom #autismblogger #specialneedsblogger #disabilities

You don’t need to do this program.

I know that’s the opposite of what the company would want me to say, but I don’t care. Everyone has their own personal path and you certainly don’t have to take mine.

And the truth is, it doesn’t matter if you do this program or another one or none at all. I only hope you end up where I am now: with a sense of pride and stability and self-love.

(All foreign emotions for a girl who used to hide in photos and stick her head in a toilet bowl.)

But I also want you to know that this program changed my entire life. And I’ve coached enough people to know it’s changed theirs too.

So since my job is to story tell, not sell, I want to tell you this:

The only reason I’ve survived abuse, anxiety, autism, heart disease, cancer, miscarriages and more is because I prioritized myself.

Your circumstances may never change—but you can. You can. And even if it’s not this program, my prayer is that you follow whatever lights a fire within you until it becomes a flame.

Time doesn’t heal anything—it’s what we do with that time that matters. And if your path leads you to this program, I’ll be ready.

No path should be walked alone.

#autismmom #specialneedsmom #autismblog #bodydysmorphia #anxietyawareness #ptsdrecovery

Neither her gymnastics teacher nor myself knew Campbell’s neurotype when this video was taken. He just recognized she was kind to her friends and didn’t forget a thing.

That’s all still true.

Sometimes people don’t even know they’re in the presence of someone with autism. Or that they likely already have a friend or colleague or spouse on the spectrum.

I find that fascinating and frustrating. I wish people were more vocal about their neurodiversity so that me and my children felt less alone.

So that‘s why I share. Because maybe someone who’s fearful of a diagnosis will see my daughter on that podium and realize she’s not kind and brilliant in spite of her autism.

She’s kind and brillant because of it.

Autism isn’t a diagnosis to be shamed away.

It’s something, in this family, we applaud.

#autism #autismmom #girlswithautism #autismlove #disabilityawareness #specialneedskids

To the Mom at the Beginning of a Diagnosis,

I want to reassure you, it won’t always be like this.

It won’t always be overturned furniture and behavioral meltdowns and scripting with no end in sight.

I know that seems like a lie. You’re in the thick of it now. You’re living an unexpected life, which feels hard and unfair because often times it is.

But here’s what I want you to know:

All kids learn and grow (and so will you).

And while I would never offer false reassurance—sometimes behaviors last and speech issues linger—I will remind you of this:

Even if a child isn’t “cured” a parent can be.

We can change. We can change our outlook and priorities and the people we bring into our lives. Eight years into the game of autism, I no longer see that broken dresser as a bad thing. It was simply a little boy trying to reach me.

And he did.

Autism broke me wide open and what remained was a really hard yet incredibly beautiful life.

The most problematic behavior is an outdated perspective. So your only job right now is to trade expectation for appreciation and learn to love the child before you. Reckless, foolish, illogical, unconditional love.

Well, that and support. There is no shame in not knowing it all. Find the people who best understand your circumstances and run fiercely into their arms.

Sometimes things break so healing can begin.

Love,

A mother who’s been there

#disability #autismmom #specialneedsmom #autismfamily #neurodivergent #autismblogger

Dear future friend,

I’m writing to you with a bit of a warning. I know on the outside I look super appealing. I am, after all, a woman who works out three times per week and alphabetizes her spice rack.

But I can’t move forward in our friendship by only presenting my sparkly parts; that would be unfair to both of us. So here’s what I really want you to know if we’re going to be BFF’s:

- Don’t expect a reply to every call or text. The urgency to always be “on” is exhausting for an introvert. Please understand that for my mental health I have to prioritize how much people take from me.

- I will save you from an avalanche but I will not engage in small talk. I don’t have the capacity to care about the weather or playgroup gossip. I want a relationship with the real you, not your perfect image, and we can’t get there if we’re not sharing the tough stuff.

- Please don’t be alarmed when I hold you accountable. I need the same. A friend is a mirror, someone who can show you your beauty AND your blemishes. We will not grow if we swaddle each other in all the right words.

- If you never hear me say “I’m praying for you,” it’s because I already am.

You see, I am not an easy friend to have. I will cancel dinner plans when my anxiety rises. You will have to defer to my family’s needs as I raise two children with disabilities. You will likely never see a social media comment or Christmas card from me—but what you will get in return is someone who will fight for your humanity, and wash your hair when you’ve undergone chemo, and send you a podcast or book rec full of life changing ah-ha moments. I will think of you long past the Hallmark holidays and love you through the heavy and the happy moments of life.

I’m complicated and messy but, well, I’m real.

And I only hope this is the kind of friend you’re looking for.

#autismmom #motherhoodunplugged #specialneedsmom #momswithanxiety #ptsd

Something interesting happened when we adopted Nana: we opened our home, but she opened our hearts. There is a warmth within these four walls that was missing for so long.

Thank you @cuddleclones for giving us more of her to love.

From feral to family—to with us forever.

#animaladoption #dogadoption #autismfamily #petadoption #specialneedsfamily

Yes, yes they will be left out.

If you delay smartphones & refuse social media until a time when their brains are more equipped to handle it, they will 100% get left out.

Left out of dangerous tik tok trends.

Left out of Instagram drama.

Left out of Snapchat nude pics.

Left out of comparison and body image traps.

Left out of knowing what every friend is doing without them.

Left out of mindless scrolling.

Left out of living online.

Left out of pornsites.

Left out of addictive gaming.

Left out of burning bridges.

Left out of inappropriate conversations.

Left out of incessant bullying.

Left out of possible predators.

Left out of sleepless nights.

Left out of MA shows.

Left out of explicit lyrics.

Left of out losing their innocence.

Left out of endless distractions.

Yes, they are going to be left out.

And probably left out of some friend groups & cool crowds & middle school romances & meet ups & funny memes & weekend parties.

It’s a bummer but I’ll take it.

And I’m not naive enough to think that holding off on a phone, internet or social media takes away all the junk. Of course it won’t.

But it also doesn’t open the door and usher it in with my silent blessing.

Being left out is a small price to pay for a fighting chance at becoming the person they were meant to be in this crazy, mixed up world.

And if more parents would choose this path, it would be a little less lonely.

Heck, maybe even be cool.

But even if it never is, I am 100% positive that I will stand my ground.

Because there are far worse things than being left out.

Credit: @waituntil8th #autismmom #specialneedsmom #motherhoodjourney #kidswithdisabilities #neurodiversity

social_posts.post_text:
Tomorrow I turn 38.

But this is the day I was really born.

Is there risk when you reveal your truth? Absolutely. Some people really benefit from you staying silent and small.

But my life is proof of what also can occur: connection, community. I am fully seen and loved anyhow. What luck.

Thank you for embracing my stories and my scars.

Here’s to many more years of leaking the truth.

#autismmom #specialneedsmom #autismblog #anxietyawareness #abusesurvivor #infertility #hypertrophiccardiomyopathy #kidswithautism

My husband and I have never celebrated Valentine’s Day. We don’t exchange cards on our anniversary. I can’t remember what he got me for Christmas, not this year nor any.

But last week when an ice storm hit, he canceled every single one of his meetings to take care of our kids. He encouraged me to quit my job as a nurse because he believed in my talent as a writer. He’s loved my body at over 200 pounds and every single number in between.

We may not swing from chandeliers or swoon over each other on social media, but he never leaves a room without asking me what I need.

Love isn’t always sexy; sometimes it’s just steady. It’s unconditional support.

“Real, sane, mature love—the kind that pays the mortgage year after year and picks up the kids after school—is not based on infatuation but on affection and respect.”

Men, listen to me. Women would trade every box of chocolates in the world for a 10am text reminding them of their worth.

Love someone in the little moments.

Not just when a calendar tells you to.

#autismfamily #specialneedsfamily #autismdad #autismmom #marriagequotes

On the day of my birth, I’m thinking about my death.

Not in a morbid way; in a motivating one. It is the idea that I will die that gives me the urgency to live.

And that’s exactly what I did for my birthday. With my Sissy in tow, I set out to have new experiences. I didn’t want cake and balloons, I wanted novelty.

So thank you @hostedbymarisol @dingdinggroupboxing @sweathouzwestvillage @goapeplano for making me feel alive again.

“At no age will I be content to take my place by the fireside and simply look on. Life was meant to be lived.”

Happy birthday to me.

#autismmom #specialneedsmom #momswithanxiety #autismblog #depressionawareness

We’re skipping an important step when it comes to trauma recovery.

Yes, survival can unveil strength. But that’s an end goal after a lot of healing has been done.

Hard stuff happens. Brutal, inhumane, unthinkable stuff happens. And we need to stop glossing over trauma as if it automatically reveals the best in us.

What doesn’t kill you doesn’t make you stronger.

What you do with your pain does.

What made me stronger wasn’t my trauma, it was…me. It was therapy. It was reading books by people who have been through similar circumstances. It was medication and prayer. It was protecting myself by setting firm boundaries.

Time doesn’t heal anything—it’s what you do with that time that matters.

So to all my trauma survivors: that shitty thing that happened to you didn’t give you strength.

But you persevering through an unplanned life damn sure did.

#abusesurvivor #mentalhealthawareness #anxietyrecovery #momswithdepression #autismmom #specialneedsmom

Trying new foods has been the slowest and most painful process for my kids. I like big leaps in development and this has been baby steps at best.

A few tips we’ve gathered along the way:

1. Always present the new food on their plate, even if you know they won’t eat it. If they’re not ready for visual tolerance, start by doing a family style plate in the middle of the table.

2. As you eat the new food, make exaggerated declarations of how it tastes:

“These ribs are SO soft! I barely have to chew.”

“This meat slides around on my tongue. It’s smoky and smooth.”

3. Move your jaw around. Show them the food in your mouth. It’s probably comedic to watch, but it lessens anxiety while highlighting the mechanics of eating.

4. Let them get messy. Take away utensils. Exploring with their hands will help them know what to expect in their mouthes.

5. Get really good at waiting. This process is long and arduous. But one day, when you least expect it, your daughter might ask for a BBQ rib.

Everything in their own time.

#kidswithautism #girlswithautism #boyswithautism #feedingtherapy #occupationaltherapy #autismmom #autismfamily

I will never forget when I was told I take too many breaks.

My kids were both toddlers—both in the process of receiving an autism diagnosis—and my husband’s heart was actively failing.

With no family nearby, I assumed the role of full-time caregiver (to everyone except myself).

Those were the years my mental health took a real nosedive.

So any chance I got, I snuck away for a Starbucks run or an aimless stroll around Target. Tiny moments that amounted to something big.

And that is when someone said to me, “My generation never took this many breaks.”

I have great admiration for the mothers who came before me. But may I suggest that smiling on cue and never asking for help is not a badge of honor—it’s a betrayal to yourself.

You were a woman before children, and while it’s natural to press pause in order to care for your family, it is by no means a requirement to not care for yourself. Motherhood shouldn’t be complete martyrdom. You don’t need to go without to give your kids more. In fact, I think one of the greatest burdens our children can bear is to witness is the unlived life of a parent.

So yes, I take breaks. I pour into my own cup so I can continue to pour into theirs. I don’t smile on cue; I share my struggles so that I can find real support.

You don’t get more points for mothering exhausted and alone.

You just model to your children that when they become parents their needs should go unfulfilled too.

#motherhoodunited #autismmom #specialneedsmom #autismblog #momswithanxiety

If you come to me and tell me you want to be skinny, you’ve got the wrong coach. Body type isn’t my focus here, health is.

I have now coached people from 17-82 years old. Those with 10 pounds to lose and those with over 200. Their goals all differ, but mine is always the same: to help people get healthy. 

Whether that be in mind or body (it’s almost always both).

No exercise needed; small nutritional changes got all of us there.

Here’s to loving the bodies we’ve been given…and elongating the time they get to walk this wonderful earth.

#bodyimage #autismmom #specialneedsmom #autismblogger #momswithanxiety

I was filling out an autism evaluation for my daughter when one question stopped me in my tracks:

“What expectations do you have for your child’s future?”

The suggested options gutted me—college, live independently, supported employment. Not because I think they’re impossibilities, but because I think they’re irrelevant.

When my children were both diagnosed with autism, I deeply grieved the life I thought I would have. The milestones most parents feel entitled to became big question marks for me.

But when you love someone with a disability, you inevitably emerge with a new set of eyes. You begin to see beauty that others miss.

So that’s how I answered the question; through my new lens:

“Should Campbell choose, I assume she would be able to attend college and live independently. Our main concern has little to do with academics, but rather that of acceptance. Can we equip this child with the skills needed to connect with her peers and environment—and can we also teach her how to cope when the acceptance she so readily gives others isn't reciprocated.”

Graduations and grandchildren aren’t the only markers of a life well lived.

I just want my babies to be accepted.

What a beautiful future that would be.

How did I get my two children with autism to progress?

It wasn’t just the programs—it’s the place. And most importantly, the people.

Almost two years ago we enrolled our children at @therapyandbeyond It was here we finally were able to merge their services directly into a school setting with individualized academics. Social skills, ABA, speech and OT—real life application with peer role models.

There’s no better way to learn.

But I can say with confidence, the sole reason this clinic has worked for us for so long is because of the people who line its walls. Therapists who have forged connections when others couldn’t. Clinic directors who know our family as names, not numbers. I can breathe and begin again as a mother because we now have a team who is an extension of our family.

Kids feel that kind of love.

And love changes everything.

If you are a caregiver and have questions, please let me know. They have clinics in Texas, Oklahoma and Colorado.

And if you are someone wanting to work with children like mine, also reach out. I know they’re widening the Therapy and Beyond family and they’d be lucky to have you.

How did my kids progress?

We found people who saw their amazing potential and made learning fun.

And now every day, my children get to run into the arms of unconditional acceptance.

Sometimes I think my kids with autism are at an advantage.

A few years ago, I never would’ve imagined saying that, let alone believing it to be true. But since the age of two, my children have spent countless hours in therapy learning to identify, express, and healthily manage their emotions. 

And if you ask me, those particular skills, if taught to every child early on, could save lives and help remedy the extreme mental health crisis our country has.

My daughter is eight. She spent her morning making thinking putty to donate to the “chill zone” at her school. She wants every child to know that it’s okay to hurt and be human and that there are things that can help the hard feelings we face.

Academics are secondary to me. You can be a star student or athlete and be crippled inside with anxiety. We have to give children the tools to understand this incredibly complex world.

And maybe the peace we want for them all starts with a little putty.

“Why do you think people don’t move forward with the program?”

This is a text from one of my clients. We were chatting about the freedom Optavia has brought us and what holds people back from trying it.

I told her at first I thought it was the price. But $13 for 5 meals per day can usually be budgeted, especially since the program is short-term. These are never intended to your forever foods.

Then I thought maybe it was me. I’m a stranger on the internet, after all. I hope that’s not the perception after so many years of sharing my life, but it would certainly be understandable.

But then I realized people probably don’t move forward for the same reason I didn’t for so long (even after seeing one of my BFFs succeed):

Because change is hard. And oftentimes we don’t change until we become so uncomfortable that we’re forced to.

That’s where I was at when I finally said yes: desperate. On diabetic meds. Emotionally bingeing then restricting. Hiding in photos behind my kids. Turning away from my husband’s touch.

That discomfort made me say yes to something I was skeptical of, and the 12 weeks it took me to lose 35lbs has changed the last 2.5 years of my life.

So here’s my promise to you: honesty. Always.

I am a women’s health RN with a deep passion to help people. I share about this program with the same enthusiasm as I share my favorite TV shows (excuse me, VPR scandal?!). When I find something that brings me joy, I want everyone in my life to experience it too.

So here I am: storytelling, not selling. And if the road leads you to this particular type of change, I’m here to walk with you.

This is what fighting for my mental health looks like.

People always say, “I wish they would’ve sought help.”

But did you ever think, maybe they have?

Sometimes the first medication doesn’t work—or the fourth. There’s only one way to reset a bone, but many ways to rewire a brain. It’s the part of healing no one ever talks about: that it isn’t always easy or linear.

It’s a long process to find peace.

And it’s also a process people with mental illness fight alone. Our wounds aren’t visible so they’re easy to ignore. We are hushed by society; labeled as an inconvenience. Shamed and stigmatized. So when a therapist says the wrong thing, or the first prescription fails, the person suffering often thinks, fine. I’m okay. I’m not bleeding out.

And yet we’re actively dying.

Seek help, sure. Then get ready to pivot and swerve when it doesn’t work. It’s excruciating and exhausting to exist in a world without support.

But our lives are worth it.

One year ago, I was ready to walk out of my marriage.

I felt unseen. Not unloved, there is a notable difference between those two words. I have never been unloved by my husband and I’m very thankful for that.

But somewhere along the line, my emotional needs began to blend into the background. We were partners and parents with zero passion between us.

A co-existing machine without a single spark.

So what made me stay? Well, I’ll unpack that soon. But what I will say for now is that our first marriage did indeed end. And this January, we drove to Austin and began a new one.

We celebrated ten years of marriage, not with extravagance, but by renting the most perfect space from @stayateverly and just staying still and staying together.

Most of us will have two or three marriages or adult relationships in our lifetime.

Some of us will do it with the same person.

My husband’s heart stopped and both of my kids were diagnosed with autism in the same year. I am no stranger to grief and the loneliness that accompanies it.

During that time, a lot of very good and well-intended people did a lot of very good and well-intended things.

But if I could make one small amendment, it would be this:

Stop saying “I can’t imagine what you’re going through.”

Because the truth is, you can.

Close your eyes and imagine picking your spouse up off the floor. Imagine your children unable to speak. Think about having to bury your most beloved friend or losing a baby six months into your pregnancy.

It is possible to imagine what a person is going through—we just usually don’t want to because proximity to pain makes us uncomfortable. If we “go there,” if we let ourselves truly imagine what they’re experiencing, we have to experience it too.

And that’s uncomfortable.

But it’s also where true empathy is found.

So the next time a loved one expresses something hard, instead of saying “I can’t imagine,” try this:

“I can imagine. I have been imagining it every single second since you shared it with me. I know this is hard and unfair and I also know you are not in this alone because I am here.”

Changing your can’t to can will change someone’s life.

And your entire relationship with them.

#autismmom #hypertrophiccardiomyopathy #autismblog #disabilityawareness #inclusionmatters #specialneedsfamily

To the Mom at the Beginning of a Diagnosis,

I am writing to you from the floor of a convention center.

I brought my six-year-old autistic son to a Lego festival. There are booths and building stations and busyness all around us. It is loud and crowded. And yet, here I sit. He is within eyesight, but he is alone; building. I am reminded by my social media memories that these days, not so long ago, were a complete impossibility. That there were years where we went no where, and when we did, I was flooded with envy at the other moms who could let their children play without worry.

It felt like we’d never arrive at a destination most families were lucky enough to be born into.

But here we are.

You may wonder how we progressed to this point—and the oversimplified answer would be this:

We never stopped exposing him.

And we never stopped supporting him.

One would not have worked without the other. He needed to be out in the world—but not without the right tools.

Our goal has never been to change Eli, but to enhance him. Our children deserve every opportunity that this unaccommodating world offers.

And we deserve to sit.

So even though things seem bleak and impossible at present day, never say never.

Anything can happen. Anything can be.

Today is World Autism Day but I have nothing left to say about autism. I’m tired of begging for awareness and acceptance and inclusion.

I just want to speak directly to the two people in this photo.

Campbell and Eli,

I have spent the last six years advocating for a diagnosis I don’t live with. I experience autism only through your eyes, and as you age, I hope you will see that my efforts have been to change others and never to change you.

I am so sorry you were born into a world that values productivity over personhood. One where identity will never matter as much as achievement. I’m sorry that you will face stigma and shame simply because your brain works differently.

And yet—

I will never apologize for autism.

It is a difference not a deficit.

It would be unfair to not acknowledge the challenges you have, and will continue to, face. But as we discussed last week, everyone has their hard. Everyone has difficulties that either cripple them with fear or require them to rise into resilience.

And I’ve never met two humans so unafraid of the fire.

I know you were given this diagnosis to teach others that there is no need for division or prejudice because all people, all brains, are considered beautiful. You deserve the acceptance you so readily give others, and I hope I live long enough to see days like this become obsolete because neurodivergence becomes the norm.

You hold the power to shift that narrative.

Campbell and Eli, I love you just the way you are.

And I’ll keep fighting until everyone else does too.

What do you consider a win?

Is it points scored? A division record? The fact that your child had more play time than others?

Autism reshaped what wins are for our family. A few years ago, my son was unable to compete on a team. He didn’t understand the dynamic of turn-taking or rule following. He rejected the idea of anything new. In his eyes, if he couldn’t do it perfectly it wasn’t worth doing at all.

Now here he is. Six years old. Part of a team that values him. Linking arms with the players. Cheering on their wins over his own.

My daughter has eaten the same handful of foods her entire life.

It’s not for lack of effort. It’s just that some kids with autism are sensitive to sounds or textures, but for our family, that sensitivity extends to food.

It’s been the most frustrating and slowest progressing part of our special needs journey.

Recently I enrolled Campbell at @youngchefsacademy and from the very first class, I knew something was different. She was taking pride in what she was preparing. Being exposed to different ingredients and textures. Immersing her senses. Using fine motor skills to grate and chop and sauté. Socializing! Working with peers and seeing them delight in trying new foods made her willing to do so too.

She has tried a bite of every single meal she’s made.

I wouldn’t believe this miracle if I didn’t witness it myself.

Sometimes, when all hope seems lost, we don’t abandon the plan—we pivot.

Chef Campbell, I’m so proud of your perseverance.

You are the flavor in our life.

My daughter has autism. For her birthday, she asked for one thing:

To visit the rescue where we adopted our dog, Nana.

There’s a particular reason why she made this request.

Because every dog at The Pawerful Rescue has a story.

So we spent our afternoon listening to each one. Some of the dogs had been inhumanely neglected, forced to fight, abandoned in their senior years. Others were born with paralysis, amputated, dismissed and discarded merely because of their disability.

And yet, all of them were filled with endless joy. The direct result of two people who have devoted their entire lives to remembering the forgotten.

Love changes everything.

There’s a palpable sense of hope out on that piece of land. The pups feel it, and so did we. Watching my daughter connect with each animal reminded me how undeserving we are of dogs—and people with disabilities.

They may be the only ones who offer unconditional acceptance.

And what a wonderful world it would be if—no matter what someone’s story—we did the same.

But not me. Nothing gives me greater peace than knowing my kids are sustainable without me.

So we had a beautiful conversation about childhood memories, and the passing of the torch, and that one day, should she choose, these traditions will belong to her too.

I’m not okay.

This is how I spent the night. With a chair blocking my already dead bolted door.

I wish I could say this paranoia only happens when I’m at a hotel, but that would be a lie. It happens at home. It happens when a person looks at me a little too long in a store. It happens, mainly and mostly, in my head, all day long.

There is a lot of trauma in my veins. Of course the obvious kind: I’ve been a victim of abuse. But also the kind a lot of women probably experience:

My body is unsafe in this world.

The other day we were having a piece of furniture delivered and my husband wasn’t going to be home. I dress rehearsed what I would do if the drivers tried to attack me.

These are thoughts a man never has to think.

I do realize I am an extreme. Not all people are this anxious and not all people are predators.

But my nervous system doesn’t know that.

I live in a constant state of hypervigilance. I know every exit in a restaurant. I know when someone’s eyes are on me a little too long. It’s excruciating and exhausting and it is my life.

So the only way I cope is by focusing on what I can control:

A deadbolt, a chair, and my thoughts.

For today, I am safe.

For today, I am safe.

The reason why I wanted to get healthy goes much deeper than vanity.

I have to two children with autism. They are elopers—which means they will run away at a moments notice. They are also very quickly outgrowing me. Anyone with a child on the spectrum knows that breakdowns require a great deal of brut strength.

I needed to keep up. I needed to not be out of breath when chasing them or lifting their dead weight from the floor.

I needed them to have a present mom who wasn’t lost in emotional eating or body dysmorphia.

I didn’t do a nutrition program just so I could look a certain way. Was that a part of it? Sure. I’d be lying if I said it isn’t fun to order a shirt and have it actually fit when it arrives.

But my why?

I needed to care for myself—before I was no longer able to care for them.

(*I talk about this program intermittently so I don't overwhelm people with unwanted info, but I'm still very much active in coaching and happy to chat with anyone who wants to know more.

Sometimes the most unlikely things end up saving your life.)

During that trip, our son had so many behavioral episodes we almost had to leave. Our daughter was too hyperactive to hike. And my fight or flight from stored trauma was activated, causing even me to want to flee.

“Holy shit. How did we get here?”

Progress churns like a slow wheel. You sometimes don’t see it—until you do. And then you can’t look away.

I am actively watching my child separate from me.

Campbell recently told me no more braids. No more butterflies on her water bottles. For the first time, she wants to shop for her own clothes and redecorate her own room.

Part of me is thrilled: these are typical developmental milestones I didn’t know if she’d ever care about.

But the other part, the part of me who wants full control of everything (and everyone), suddenly feels off-kilter.

Because I know I’m witnessing a beginning.

This is the beginning of the human I created creating a separate identity from me. It’s the beginning of us not always being in alignment or agreement.

It is, in truth, a personal crossroad.

I could immediately put a braid back in her hair and tell her I know better.

Or, I could relinquish control and see what she becomes without me.

Something tells me the latter is what will connect us even more.

Our children may choose hairstyles, or lifestyles, that differ from ours. They may grow up to marry different people or believe in different things. They may not live out our preferred plan, but that’s because those plans never belonged to them in the first place.

Our goal shouldn’t be to raise a blindly compliant child.

It should be to raise a confident one.

Over the weekend, there was a mass shooting ten minutes from my house.

Why haven’t I commented? Well, because I don’t have the same scripted response as everyone else.

“We’re so shocked and surprised”

Really? This is the 190th mass shooting so far this year.

“My thoughts and prayers are with the victims”

Fantastic. Valued and valuable. But what about your actions too? Jesus prayed for people AND he used his hands and feet to create systemic change.

I’m tired of seeing the memes floating around featuring the state of Texas. They’ll soon be replaced by another state, another school. Another church, theatre, or club. People will return to their daily lives; the lives lost won’t. Nothing will change.

I hesitated to post because I don’t want to turn this into a political battle; I just want to make it a personal one.

Because whether you’re for or against guns—for or against preventative support for mental health—the truth is, violence has existed since the beginning of time. Open a Bible and you’ll see just that.

The difference now is that we can actually put systems in place to save someone.

Posting a meme (and moving on) simply isn’t enough.

Every time Campbell has a piano recital, I have to actively bite my lip to keep from bawling.

I’ve never felt God more than when I listen to the disabled community sing and strum and play without any sense of ego or pride.

Some are future Mozarts. Some are totally off key. It doesn’t even matter. It’s all so incredibly holy.

And l think I know why:

These kids are so embodied.

No pretending. No performing. No obsession over what clothes they’re wearing or if their best side is showing. No shame if they skip a note or need to start over. Just one whole and perfect human.

To live like that? My gosh.

It’s music to my ears.

It’s a celebratory day when you find a product that is perfect for families of all abilities.

So happy birthday, my girl. You are so deserving of this space and this surprise.

The image of you grabbing your heart will forever be cemented in mine.

On this day, S E V E N years ago, our son, Eli Judd Hanrahan, arrived.

I want to tell you a very vulnerable story about his birth.

When Eli was born, he couldn’t open his eyes. For three long excruciating days, I watched him squint and try to pry and then give up. Pediatricians circled in and out, and I was convinced, even though all the prenatal testing had been normal, that the doctors had missed something. I kept repeating to my husband over and over again, "Something is wrong with him."

(That was the beginning of something being wrong with me—severe postpartum depression.)

But Shawn, the steady man that he is, just kept reassuring me that he was fine. And if he wasn't, he was still fine. He was ours.

Our perfect son.

And then, late into the evening on the third day, I peered over my hospital bed into that tiny bassinet and found, sure enough, open eyes. He had done it quietly, no grand announcement or proclamation. He just laid there looking around, taking in his new world. Letting me know early on that everything he did would be done in his own time.

And that’s been his pattern ever since.

Eli is no show horse. He doesn’t demand center stage. He saves every dollar he earns. He wanted nothing more on his birthday than to do a water balloon fight. The same thing he asked for last year.

My son, you have taught me that a quiet life is not a lesser one. In fact, a slower pace means more chances to see the beauty.

And my eyes are wide open to you.

Happy birthday to the boy who still surprises me.

Always in his own time.

For the months following my husband’s heart stopping, and his spine shattering, we only have pictures of him in two places:

Park benches and beds.

That summer, while broken hearts and broken bones were introduced into our daily dialogue—and I struggled to keep a six week old and two year old alive—my husband shifted from family leader to someone who could no longer feed, dress, bathe, or toilet himself.

But somehow during the middle of his crisis, he still managed to show up for us.

Every time I took the kids to the park or the pool, he came too—sitting in a chair, watching over his family.

And if we were home? He’d request to have his newborn son placed on his chest.

At the time I was so afraid and exhausted, it just felt like a dad tagging along; unable to provide for his family in the way he once did before.

But now these photos serve as markers of survival. Visual images of our overcoming. How lucky are my children to have a father who put aside his pain to be present?

How lucky am I that we have lived long enough to retry our love?

My husband may not be great at pretend play, but there’s nothing fake about his feelings for us. 

We will never doubt where we stand with this man.

Because we always know he will sit with us.

To the person who called my autistic son the “R” word,

I’m not here to defend my child’s disability.

I’m not even here to tell you how defamatory that word is (because that should be a given).

I just want to offer you the kind of understanding that you failed to give us.

My son doesn’t have impaired cognition. He doesn’t have any physical markers of a disability (certainly none you could identify in a thirty second clip). Which means you aren’t associating him with being “R,” you’re associating autism in general as that.

And if we’re going to reframe that narrative (for you, and society as a whole), I need you to hear me say this:

Autism isn’t a disease—it’s a divergence.

There is nothing to cure here except the warped, outdated idea of what is considered valuable in our culture.

My children have brains that work differently, but not deficiently. Autism, although it presents unique challenges, has amazing assets too. I absolutely love that my children care less about clothing and more about kindness. I adore that they ask questions others wouldn’t even dare to think.

And do you want to know the coolest part about autism?

You can offer the hate you did to my son—and he’d still respond with radical love.

Autism isn't wrong. It's the most right version of life I've ever witnessed.

So I’m not going to let society backslide.

I hope I live long enough to see that word eradicated from everyone’s vocabulary.

And also to see neurodiversity become a norm.

Sparks fade—but steady love is forever.

Seven years ago today, I found my husband unresponsive on our bedroom floor.

The incision from my c-section had barely healed. I had a baby on my breast and a two-year-old who was beginning to flap her hands.

He had to get up.

And he did.

But only because, on his way down, he broke his back on our nightstand. The jolt of shattering his spine restarted his heart.

If he would’ve fallen gracefully to the carpet, I’d be a widow right now.

It is on this day, and many other days in between, I remember the gift of compounded pain. That right when you believe another straw will break you—it saves your life.

I can be angry that this happened (and that we continue to be swallowed whole by the unknown) and also eternally thankful.

Thankful for that nightstand.

Thankful the second (and third) cardiac arrest didn’t happen while he was driving our children.

Thankful we can hold two feelings at once.

We can celebrate seven years—and still be afraid of what happens from here.

AUTISTIC versus PERSON WITH AUTISM

Which is correct?

I was always taught to use person-first language because it frames a diagnosis as something a person “has” rather than something they “are.” A PERSON WITH AUTISM. I was told it was polite, respectful.

A person is so much more than their autism, right?

But there’s a beautiful movement by autistic adults which strongly disagrees.

The widespread consensus (up to 76% in some studies) suggests that being called AUTISTIC is preferable because autism is inseparable from one’s very being.

Autism isn’t something you “have,” like the common cold or diabetes. You can’t set it down when you desire. It’s ingrained into every interaction, relationship, and experience within this world.

It’s not a diagnosis—it’s an identity.

And being unable to acknowledge that feeds the beast of shame and ableism.

Personally, I’m in favor of anything that honors someone’s identity, but I only represent two people on the spectrum. So until they can express what feels most right to them, we’ve chosen to use the terms interchangeably. Individual preferences should always be top priority—as should listening to the people actually experiencing it.

But here’s the hard truth: we still don’t have enough voices sharing about autism to get hindered down by semantics. Call it what you will, just speak loudly (and respectfully) enough until the stigma of neurodiversity goes away.

I’ve got two autistic kids counting on it.

Eating does not begin in the mouth.

That was my misconception when it came to my children’s food challenges for far too long.

As I started to learn more about why they struggled to not only try new foods, but even visually tolerate them on their plates, I learned how complex the act of eating actually is.

Eating requires:

👃All five senses
🧠Organ systems (digestive, respiratory)
💪Muscle movement (chewing, postural support)
📢Conditions within the environment (noise)

All working together—all potential challenges for someone with autism.

There’s a fine line between pushing and pulling back when it comes to our children. But my job as their mother is to keep them safe and that includes nourishing their bodies (eating at a restaurant was never the expectation, although certainly an added bonus since it’s so coveted in our culture).

So we kept going—and leaving early. We kept exposing.

And most of all, we kept in mind the Māori word for autism:

Everything in their own time.

At the beginning of the summer, I made a desperate call:

“My son has autism accompanied by a side of perfectionism. He refuses to read or write and he’s starting public school for the very first time this fall. I need help.”

Without hesitation, a teacher—a woman with her own family who deserves nothing more than a fun and frivolous summer—said:

Bring him to me.

In three sessions, he was reading. By the end of the summer, he was writing sentences—misspelled words and all. He even signed a contract stating he’d let go of perfectionism and commit to doing his personal best.

Teachers, let me tell you what your time and talent means to families like mine:

You have given my son tools to navigate this world; to live a more independent and enriched life. He now has the ability to communicate his thoughts in written form, read signs at a store, and enter a classroom this fall with confidence and ease.

I know you have to navigate through a lot of red tape, but I’m begging you to keep cutting down the barriers. Remain inspired by the fact that there are children with autism (and those without) who will one day close a book and look out the car window with a newfound sense of pride—and that will be a direct result of you.

Your offerings do not go overlooked. You are the most vital part of our village.

Thank you for believing in my child.

So he can finally believe in himself.

It’s not uncommon to call a teacher a superhero. They are, after all, capable of miraculous acts.

But superheroes are autonomous; they don’t need our help. They win every battle and emerge victorious, ready to fight again. No risk. No collateral damage. No rest necessary.

That’s not the case for our beloved educators.

There’s an enormous cost that comes from prioritizing someone else’s child over your own. A hardship that accompanies doing life-altering work for massively low wages. Teachers need more than a Starbucks card and a random superlative. They need universal childcare and administrative support and parents who teach their children social-emotional regulation instead of putting them in front of screens all day.

Sure, there are some similarities between caped crusaders and our fierce classroom comrades, but we have to stop minimizing their very real and important needs.

Teachers are superheroes—but only because they have to be.

So this year as school resumes, as mothers like me trust the safety of their most beloved to ordinary humans with an extraordinary set of gifts, let’s call them superheroes—

And also offer tangible support.

“Your children aren’t autistic.”

I receive that comment on an almost daily basis.

To the creators of the Barbie movie,

Over the weekend, I took my nine-year-old autistic daughter to see your blockbuster hit. I didn’t want to go with a gaggle of girlfriends, but rather with the one girl who needed this message the most.

After the movie wrapped, we drove home having one of our deepest discussions to date. A conversation about equal pay and exploitation and the steep mountains women must climb.

She burst into tears.

And then she went and told her little brother all about it. This is the conversation I walked in on.

I want to applaud you for the way this movie was marketed. Your roped women in under the guise of hot pink and high heels because otherwise they would’ve resisted the depth.

It’s part of our conditioning.

Stay distracted. Stay surface. Stay quiet.

But I also know this movie is not just for women. It’s for the little boy at the top of those stairs who has proximity to power simply because of his gender and skin tone.

Even if he never becomes a CEO, I guarantee he will honor equality within his own home, if only because he has a sister and mother moved to tears by a doll named Barbie.

Thank you for creating conversation and making people uncomfortable.

The status quo never changes until those two things occur.

Sincerely,

More than a mom

Somewhere along the line it’s become socially acceptable to water down disability and mental illness.

It’s become slang—

“I have anxiety about my upcoming interview.”

“I forgot to pick up the dry cleaning. I’m so ADD!”

The common use of these terms seems benign, but in actuality it minimizes a diagnosis, making it harder for people in crisis to get proper care.

There’s a big difference between the nerves you feel when taking a test and the kind of anxiety that causes intrusive thoughts.

ADHD isn’t just misplacing car keys. It can impact someone’s ability to work, eat, sleep and survive.

This is about more than just using the wrong word at the wrong time. Misrepresentation can cause people with real mental health challenges to not be taken seriously when they’re suffering. It creates a “we all feel that way sometimes” mentality, which results in underdiagnosis and a lack of empathy.

Words matter. So my vote is to express our emotions as they arise—but reserve using medical terminology for individuals actually experiencing it.

We must stop diluting diagnoses.

#mentalhealth #disabilityawareness #anxietysupport #neurodivergent #disabilitypride

The best way I’ve found to increase communication with my two autistic kiddos?

Talk to them in the car.

Research shows the same part of your brain that controls eye contact is also responsible for processing language.

Since eye contact can be uncomfortable for some individuals with autism, we’ve found it most effective to provide opportunities for our kids to connect when eye contact is off the table. This has improved both their expressive and receptive language, as they are more fluid in their communication to me, but also better able to process the information I’m providing.

Almost every important conversation we’ve ever had takes place while I’m driving (or sitting outside their shower).

Small accommodation. Big communication.

My body dysmorphia has never been this bad.

It’s ironic. The smaller I get, the bigger and louder the voices in my head grow.

“You’re not good enough, Stephanie. Not yet.”

Likely not ever.

Body positivity dumbfounds me. “Love the skin you’re in!” How does one do that when there’s so much noise telling us otherwise? How does one do that when they’re disconnected from their body? Trauma entered, I exited. I’ve long been good at maintaining appearances but loving thyself feels foreign and unattainable.

I know what I must do to temper this though. I’ve been here before. And it has nothing do with a better diet or mirror affirmations.

I must busy my brain.

My brain, when stagnant, looks for something to attack. It’s favorite victim being me.

So I have to give it something else to feast on:

A good book. Working on my writing. A walk. Air. Heat. The scent of a pumpkin spice candle far too early into fall.

Truth.

Mental health is wild, and often so lonely.

I spent the last few weeks traveling the Mediterranean, a celebration (and bucket list item) for my Sissy’s fortieth birthday.

Almost every single person I encountered along the way expressed utter shock, not only that I was solo, but that my husband was responsible for our children while I was away.

I went home and asked him, “When you travel, for work or play, does anyone seem surprised your wife is watching your kids?”

He replied, “No one even asks.”

It’s assumed women, regardless of employment status, are the primary caregivers, and a man who steps up in her absence deserves a tremendous amount of applause.

I think this is a dangerous web we weave.

It sends the message that even if a woman has a job outside of the home, her rightful place is within in. And perhaps even worse, that men are incompetent in regards to child rearing. What a risky move for me to cross an ocean and leave my kids with their own father!

Just as women become whole people by being active outside the home, men become whole people by being active within it.

But shifting this narrative won’t come from just our companions, it comes from us. From women willing to demand that their partnership consist of two equal parts.

I may have carried our babies in my body.

But we will both carry them throughout this life.

Five years ago, I lost my son. I lost my two-year-old autistic son at the worst place possible: a water park.

He went down the slide (where it was required he remove his life vest), ran a few feet ahead of me, turned a corner and was gone.

It was as quick as that.

I dove in and couldn’t find him. I ran around and couldn’t find him. I started calculating the seconds, the minutes. How long does it take for a toddler to drown? Whatever the answer, I was pretty sure we were past that.

Then, I screamed for help. People ran, whistles blew. A young man with an internal calm stayed with me and said they’d find my boy. 

In what condition, I wondered.

And then, after what felt like forever, a young girl walked over a bridge carrying him on her hip.

He had gone behind a building to play.

There is no greater fear than losing a child. I lost mine—and we lived to tell about it. We are the lucky ones.

They say it takes a village to raise a child, but it takes a village to save one too. That day, some unlikely heroes showed up, and in the five years since, many more have rescued our family:

The instructor who spent her summer teaching him to swim. The therapists who taught him to speak. The parents who finally can rest (somewhat) at ease while their son floats independently down a lazy river.

Scream for help. Not just in emergent situations, but in every day life.

It’s too much to go at it alone.

#autismmom #autistickids #disabilityadvocate #neurodiversity #specialneedsfamily

When both of my children were diagnosed with autism, I could not conceptualize calling it a disability.

They were differently-abled. They had special needs. Some would even say au-some.

But as I dug deeper into neurodiversity, listening to actually autistic individuals, I learned just how damaging those cutesy euphemisms can be.

As one of my best teachers on autism quotes:

“Disability isn’t a bad word and being disabled isn’t a bad thing. Being disabled means needing accommodations because your body or mind differs from the norm to which society is catered. Calling a disabled person disabled isn’t being ableist; shying away from the term and treating it like an insult is.”

Autism is a disability. My children need accommodations to navigate this life and that’s okay. Disability is a normal part of human diversity and isn’t inherently negative—

Unless we believe it to be.

At the age of two, this is what autism looked like for my daughter.

One might argue she appears the same as any toddler, perhaps even an advanced one at that.

But it’s worth noting that two things can be true:

She can be verbal, and still be autistic.

She can be cognitively advanced, and still be autistic.

She can love singing and playing with doh, and still be autistic because autism doesn’t take away someone’s ability to be uniquely human.

Autism needs a massive rebranding. Because if we continue to rely on outdated stereotypes, not only will we miss opportunities to support neurodiverse children (and adults), we will dismiss their very identities.

My daughter isn’t brilliant and beautiful and brave in spite of her autism.

She’s brilliant and beautiful and brave because of it.

My son is seven. He is autistic—and one of the wisest people I know.

We were talking about bullying (and bossy older sisters) and Eli immediately had a solution. One that is applicable for all of us:

You don’t always have to speak.

Silence. An underrated survival strategy.

When our character has been assassinated, when someone is wrongfully unkind, it is in our nature to defend.

But not all people are worthy of our words (especially those who will twist them).

So let them spew lies.

Let them hate whatever version of you they’ve made up in their head.

Then let your truth be the loudest thing about you.

As Eli says,

“When you don’t speak back, it’s not your problem anymore.”

Silence isn’t weak. Sometimes, it’s the strongest form of retaliation. The safest way to move on.

Easy as that.

My son came home with a bite mark on his arm and here’s what I did about it:

Nothing.

His arm was bandaged; he was smiling. I signed an incident report and have enough trust in his teachers to know they handled the situation accordingly.

Do I need to be upset if he’s not? Nah.

Do I need to place blame on the other child? Certainly not.

My son may have been on the receiving end this time but he’s also been a pusher of his peers in the past. I remember back then how awful it felt, not being able to control my child’s unfavorable behavior, and I would’ve given anything to have just one mom look at me and say, “l’ve been there too. It’s okay.”

So to the parents of the child who bit mine:

It’s okay. Your child is learning. They’re doing their best and so are you. This wasn’t bullying or even intentional. It was a child who can’t verbalize his frustrations and took it out with his teeth. Oh well. They will progress, and in the meantime, you’ve given my son an opportunity to show his progression too. In the past, he would’ve retaliated. Now, he took it in stride and went about his play.

He’s fine—and your baby will be too.

We are on the same team.

Love,

A mother who’s been there

“I just want my kids to be happy.”

Let me tell you why this statement is a slippery slope:

Because there will come a day when they’re not.

I’d love if my children only experienced pleasure in their lifetime—but likely some pain will be mixed in there too.

So in this household, we prepare for it all.

If we’re anxious, we say it. If we’re sad, we sob. We don’t sugarcoat or deny our feelings because feelings were made to be felt.

And the truth is, if happiness is promoted as the only acceptable end goal, then my children will never feel comfortable coming to me if they’re anything but that.

I don’t want a “happy” household.

I want a human one—where all emotions are welcome.

And the only way that will happen is if I teach my children how to feel, not conceal.

This strategy completely changed the way I parent my two autistic kiddos and I think it’s applicable for children (and adults) of all neurotypes.

When an unexpected behavior occurs—hitting, biting, talking back—it’s our knee-jerk reaction to address the behavior with a consequence.

“You bit your sister, go to timeout.”

“You pushed your friend, no dessert for you.”

But every behavior is preceded by an antecedent, which is what caused the behavior to occur in the first place.

It’s the ABC’s of behavioral therapy:

A (antecedent)
B (behavior)
C (consequence)

So the next time your child is speaking or acting out of turn, try looking at the factors influencing that behavior. And likewise, consider the antecedents when things are going well too.

The only way to create lasting change within our children (and ourselves) is to address the why.

#autistickids #disabilityawareness #specialneedsmom #autismmom #neurodiversity

“She seems like a normal kid, not autistic.”

I receive hundreds of messages exactly like this. And while it’s not in my job description to defend, it is absolutely an advocates responsibility to educate.

So here’s my response:

Both can be true.

My daughter (and son) are autistic.

My daughter (and son) are normal.

Autism is not some curse or disease we’ve suddenly come down with. It’s not something we banish or wish away. Diversity is a normal part of nature. There are 11,000 species of birds. Is it impossible to believe a deviation of brains exists too?

My children process the world differently, but that doesn’t mean they’re wrong or deficient. It also means when someone is brave enough to disclose their diagnosis, we meet them with intrigue, not interrogation.

Maybe the way autism presents for our family is unfamiliar to you. Maybe it’s a side of the spectrum you haven’t seen.

Maybe it’s a chance to embrace someone’s autistic experience, not minimize it.

Our feathers might be colored differently.

But we’re all still birds.

I want to highlight something my daughter said here, something pretty profound:

Not only should we include people with disabilities, we need to be conscious not to ignore them as well. It’s the difference between being invited to a party (awesome, fine, thank you)—and being asked to dance (true inclusion).

But here’s a hardball I want to pitch to parents of neurotypical children. A question of accountability:

How many disabled friends do you have?

You see, it’s not enough to tell our kids to be kind and welcoming, we must show them too.

Children mimic what they most see.

So if you surround yourself only with people who look, act, and believe the same thing as you, then not only will your child miss out on the beauty of disability,

They’ll never know diversity either.

I meet a lot of parents who keep their child’s disability a secret.

Not just from the general public, but from their own child as well.

This comes with a lot of well-intentioned rationale: They don’t want them to feel different. They don’t want them to be defined by disability.

But the truth is, even without you telling them, your neurodiverse child already knows they’re different. Our society, our culture, sends them that message every single day.

Imagine your child thinking it’s their fault they can’t connect, or do simple things like wear leggings or sit at a table.

Now image a home where their disability is celebrated. Where they get to be educated and encouraged about their differences.

As a parent, you are your child’s source of truth. They look to you for confirmation. So we must remove the negative connotation from disability. We must lead by example.

Neurodiversity is a deviation, not a deficit.

The world will never accept our children if we don’t.

It’s the most wonderful time of the year (for some).

For others, the holidays can heighten isolation, or make you feel inadequate if you have less gifts under the tree or less people in your life to open them with.

For me, it’s the elf. You know, the magical one who moves from room to room until Santa comes. We’ve never participated this newfound tradition, and never will, but that doesn’t stop me from feeling like less of a mom when I see other parents and their elaborate Pinterest plans.

But then I think about the $8 pink tree I purchased from a garage sale site. We placed it in my daughter’s room, and each year she gets to buy one ornament until its branches are full.

I think about our tradition of looking at lights on Christmas Eve, and the matching pajamas and making of cinnamon rolls (from a can) on Christmas morning.

Who cares what society tells you is necessary to do. Jesus was found in a manger of hay, not on center stage.

Magic can be found in the tiniest of moments.

Food jagging. A few years ago, I had no idea what that was.

Now, I’m all too familiar.

A food jag is when a child eats the same food, prepared in the same way, so frequently that they get burned out and then that food is permanently lost from the child’s diet.

This is frightening territory for those of us with autistic kids who are sensory-adverse/problematic feeders. Often we have no choice but to serve them the same food on repeat because it’s either that or starvation.

At the very same time I’m posting the success of my daughter trying Texas Roadhouse, my son is beginning to jag on chicken nuggets. Chicken nuggets. His primary source of “protein.”

The one thing that’s served everywhere, allowing our family to finally be able to eat out together.

As frustrated and scared as I am, I am reminded that these scenarios don’t need fear and shame—they need support.

So we will continue to go to restaurants and offer him variety (even visually). And I will hold tight to the fact that the little girl in this video, the one with the “big fella baked potato,” was once a jagger herself.

Anything can happen—with hard work and hope.

#autismmom #foodtherapy #autistickids #disabledchildren #specialneedsfamily #autismblogger

Kids with autism can’t show emotion.

They aren’t empathetic.

They don’t care about relationships.

They are smart and quirky or nonverbal and cognitively delayed.

The myths surrounding autism are plentiful, and often, quite frankly, wrong.

Want to know the number one way to dispel them?

Spend time with someone on the spectrum.

My daughter and son feel emotions more than most. They laugh, they cry. They rage and run 5Ks. They have expressive language (and looks) and deeply desire to belong.

They are completely, wholly human.

And autistic.

I share our story to help negate these stereotypes. I share because, not so long ago, I was a new mother staring down a new diagnosis. Autism was unfamiliar territory, and I wish someone back then would’ve dispelled the many myths for me.

So here we are, with all our colorful layers, to let you know your true and perfect child is right beside you. They always have been.

All you have to do is look.
