To the Santa Who Made Fun of My Daughter’s Flapping,

My kids have waited all year to sit on your coveted lap. Excitement was bursting through their bodies. Which is why, when my daughter took a seat beside you, her hands began to flap and flutter with joy.

This is called stimming, a repetitive movement related to her autism. I wouldn’t expect you to know that, but I do expect Santa Claus to be a safe place where neurological differences are embraced.

You asked me, “does she always do that?” as you put your leather gloves in the air to try it yourself. Instead of inquiring about what she wants this year, you forced her to answer another question, “what are your hands doing?” as she sat there unsure of how to answer.

Santa, I want you to know that I’m not upset with you. You are not the first person to look at my family and snicker or stare. But my job as a mother is to increase awareness. So ‘tis the season for a little empathy.

You are going to see a lot of kids this year. Kids who seem fine on the surface but are deeply scarred from broken families, or drug-abused homes, or a variety of disabilities that often go unseen. They are coming to you because they believe in you.

I’m begging you to do the same.

You are a beacon of hope, Santa. You are someone who shows up, opens their arms, and says, “Come sit with me.” That’s the gift of acceptance—something families with autism often don’t receive.

So just remember, there’s a lot of joy in this world.

The fortunate few get to flap it aloud.

When you find the one who your soul loves, a space between you doesn’t exist.

Sometimes the characteristics of autism can be incredibly subtle.

What you see here is a four-year-old who wrote and read her Christmas list to Santa. It’s impressive, yes. Not many preschoolers have those skills yet.

But what I also see is a prime example of scripting, the repetition of words, phrases, or sounds from other people’s speech.

Her letter begins with a line straight out of a Christmas movie we watched several weeks prior; it’s not a free thought. In fact at that time, the large majority of her speech was not her own.

Sometimes scripts are helpful—and functional! We all use them. When someone asks “how are you?” and you reflexively respond “I’m good,” you’ve scripted. It’s a natural way to progress conversations toward an end goal.

But for kids with autism, it’s important to offer alternatives (so that eventually they can joke and wink and lie about their age).

It was beautiful back then to see our daughter find ways to engage—and it’s beautiful now to see every line on her list belong to her.

These are my Christmas miracles.

We’ve waited almost ten years for our two autistic children to join us for Christmas Eve service.

In previous years, I’d light my candle and look around the room with envy at the families experiencing these holy moments together while my children utilized the special needs ministry.

At the time, it was the best and only way we could worship—divided.

But this year, my Christmas wish came true. I had tears in my eyes as the choir sang and the candles flickered. I looked at my daughter, lost in song and prayer, and then at my son, who blessed us with a blue fire fact.

It was perfect.

Jesus doesn’t ask us to assimilate. Actually, he blessed those who were different. There are parts of the Bible where the lame (our modern day equivalent to disabled) weren’t welcomed into churches. Man, did they miss out. The closest I’ve ever been to God is when I look through the autistic lens.

Special needs families may be called to wait longer than we’d like. And when we arrive at a milestone we’ve prayed for, the reality may differ from the idea in our heads.

That’s all okay.

Our children bear the image of the Alpha and Omega as much as anyone else.

So we will enter buildings where we are welcomed.

Together—and always in our own time.

One of our daughter’s first signs of autism was a lack of joint attention.

Campbell would see something of interest—a dog, a show, a wrapped Christmas gift—and express pure delight.

But that delight was never shared with us. She had her own little world, and that point, we were rarely invited in.

She spoke solely in scripts.
She ignored her name when called.
She wandered away and would never look back.

Fast forward a few Christmases. She’s nine now, and every day she gives us the gift of connection.

It’s important to note that we never expected Campbell to change—we just offered her tools to navigate this world. What she unlocked, who she has become, is the doing of her own indestructible spirit. If she never would’ve looked up for me, I still would’ve found her.

Do not fear the future. Just give a child (autistic or not) a world worth entering.

Then let them be the guide.

Discrimination against disabled people is alive and well. In fact, I encounter ableism on a daily basis when it comes to my two autistic kiddos.

But it’s not always overtly rude comments. Sometimes the well-intended sentiments are the most damaging for the disabled population.

Here are a few examples.

Maya Angelou once said, “When we know better, we do better.” And what I know for sure is that when a community speaks, the smallest thing we can do is listen.

Being a life-longer learner is never a bad thing.

Every life matters.

Every word matters too.

On our recent trip we elected not to purchase seat assignments in order to avoid the astronomical fees. There were four of us, two being our autistic minor children, so we assumed we’d be split up with an adult present for each.

But that’s not what the airline assigned.

On all four of our flights, they put me, the mother, in a row with the kids (while Dad was in a totally different part of the plane).

While this isn’t a tragedy, it’s the implication that irked me, and to be honest, it also bothered my husband.

The assumption that kids are always a mother’s responsibility is an outdated mindset. It reinforces the idea that parenting shouldn’t be equally divided between partners.

Mothers must caretake.

Fathers can go have fun.

A woman’s job is not just within the home (or row). In fact, many women have their own careers and their own kids. But ironically enough, it is only my husband who gets applauded for “babysitting” when I’m out of town. Or a public ovation when he cooks dinner and helps with homework.

Society has to stop assuming women will do it all. Because, we will. We’re capable. But that capability creates unnecessary pressure and frankly a lot of anxiety.

It’s time to switch seats.

I erased my own post.

The other day I wrote about a store employee who made exploitive, crass comments about my body. I wrote about all the things I would’ve said, had I not been scared.

But after my post went public, I became more afraid.

Afraid he’d find me (this was a store with access to my address). Afraid he’d read my words. Afraid he’d become more enraged, then not just speak but act.

From there, the thoughts multiplied. Real or imagined—it didn’t matter. My body registered it all as a threat.

I am a survivor of sexual abuse. He couldn’t have known that, and most days, I forget too. But there are situations like these that remind me that my body believes it’s unsafe in this world and the result of that is hypervigilance. I am always alert. Always prepared.

Always, always afraid.

These are the side effects of sexual abuse often not discussed. How quickly we catastrophize. How we spiral faster than a Texas tornado.

How, even if you make a living out of speaking truth, you can be shamed into silence.

All in an effort to survive.

Our quest to expand Campbell’s palate continues.

Less than a year ago, we were down to only three items she’d actually eat. She couldn’t visually tolerate new foods on her plate, let alone take a bite of two all beef patties with special sauce.

I often get asked what got us here. Yes, we dabbled with food therapy (albeit inconsistently). Sure, we provided opportunities for repeated exposure. But more than anything, we made a game out of it. We got out a camera and started a silly food challenge. We removed the anxiety and pressure.

We let her lead.

And now?

Dadadadada, she’s lovin’ it.

*Give her some suggestions on where to go next. She reads each one and is eternally grateful*

I can’t see God unless I look through the autistic lens.

I’ve tried. I’ve tried to relate to white robes and parting clouds and a man with a beard who rules over all.

It doesn’t resonate.

It was only when I was watching my autistic children run through the snow, their hands involuntarily flapping with joy, that I finally saw the Savior.

I thought to myself, this. This is how the Devine must see me.

So now I see Him the same way.

Someone who stands in wonder over the simplest things. Someone who ignores social norms. Someone who celebrates what others can’t see.

Just like people with autism.

I’m pretty sure when I get to heaven, that’s what I’ll find: a ruler who this world overlooked.

And He will welcome me with flapping hands.
